author: MIKE RILEY sports@newsandtribune.com
title: FOOTBALL: Pirates outlast Salem, 37-27
text:
FOOTBALL: Pirates outlast Salem, 37-27 By MIKE RILEY sports@newsandtribune.com News and Tribune 
CHARLESTOWN — Two teams with similar success this season met at Charlestown Friday with the host Pirates turning back the Salem Lions 37-27 at Dutch Reis Field. 
For Charlestown (4-2, 3-2 MSC), it was their seventh consecutive win over the Lions, mainly due to a defense that, in the last six contests, had not yielded more than a single touchdown. 
Number 7 was more difficult as the Pirates trailed in the early going, but were victorious due to a dominant ground game that got an assist from the rainy conditions. 
Touchdown runs of 28 yards by Tate Boley and three yards by Syd Gieseking allowed the Pirates to overcome a 15-7 first quarter deficit to lead 21-18 at halftime. 
Salem (2-4, 1-4) did not lead in the second half, but tied the game at 21 on a 23-yard field goal by Jacob Thompson, his second of the game. 
Charlestown then took the lead for good as the Pirates drove 80 yards in seven plays late in the third quarter with Jarren Anderson going the last 46. Quarterback Brendan Lawler then kept the ball for the 2-point conversion and a 29-21 lead. 
Both teams added fourth quarter scores as Salem’s Christian Lamb caught a 17 yard touchdown pass from Seth Hobson. Anderson then scored on a 6 yard run for the Pirates and if that didn’t put the game away, then the next two plays did. 
First, Garrett Woods, acting as a holder from kick formation, threw a 2-point conversion pass to Jamal Long. After Salem took over at their own 35, a Lamb pass hung just a little too long in the air, allowing Boley the interception and the Pirates the opportunity to run clock. 
Although the Lions put more points on the board than in recent years, the Pirate defense still turned in a solid performance as they allowed only 288 yards, 133 on the ground. 
Charlestown provided 380 yards of offense with 349 coming on the ground as Lawler gained 114 yards on 10 carries while Boley gained 93 yards on 20 carries. 
Salem was led by Hobson, who completed 13-of-30 passes for 155 yards with one interception and two touchdowns. Both touchdown tosses went to to Lamb, who pulled in five Hobson passes for 71 yards. 
One thing the Pirates must correct if this season is to be successful is penalties. Against Salem, they were flagged nine times for 152 yards. 
Both teams will resume MSC play next week as Charlestown will host Corydon Central, while Salem will host Eastern. 
CHARLESTOWN 37, SALEM 27 
Salem 15 3 3 6—27 
Charlestown 7 14 8 8—37 
SCORING SUMMARY 
S — Hobson 1 run (Morris kick), 7:30. 
C — Syd Gieseking 6 run (Dalton Bowen kick), 6:35. 
S — Lamb 14 pass from Hobson (Daulton run), 1:41. 
Second quarter 
C — Tate Boley 38 run (run failed), 11:48. 
S — Thompson 27 field goal, 5:44. 
C — Gieseking 2 run (Jamal Long from Brendan Lawler), :53. 
Third quarter 
S — Thompson 23 field goal, 3:21. 
C — Lawler 43 run (Lawler run), :14. 
Fourth quarter 
S — Lamb 17 pass from Hobson (pass failed), 8:45. 
C — Jarren Anderson 6 run (Long from Garrett Woods), 3:57. 
INDIVIDUAL STATISTICS 
Rushing 
Salem (27-133): Hobson 15-102, Kalb 11-23, Akers 1-8. 
Charlestown (53-349): Lawler 10-114, Anderson 20-93, Boley 3-47, Antonyo Gaddie 6-46, Gieseking 11-42, Christian Davenport 1-7.
